comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:JONES, ALFRED JOHN
Initials:A J
Nationality:Australian
Rank:Private
Regiment/Service:Australian Infantry, A.I.F.
Unit Text:52nd Bn.
Age:21
Date of Death:04/09/1916
Service No:5120
Additional information:Son of George and Mary Ann Jones, of Beaconsfield, Tasmania. Native of Zeehan, Tasmania.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:XI. F. 11.
Cemetery:COURCELETTE BRITISH CEMETERY

comment.author: 8498561@N08
comment._content:
Private 5120 Alfred John Jones, son of George & Mary Ann Jones, Cornwall Street Beaconsfield, Tasmania.

Born Zeehan, Tasmania, enlisted  on 22/10/1915 Tasmania, aged 21 (5ft 3in tall, 136lbs), occupation labourer. 

Joined  16th Reinforcements, 12th Battalion. Following basic training embarked on R.M.S. “Orontes” Melbourne 29/03/1916. Arrived in Suez and disembarked on 15/04/1916.
Embarked at Alexandria on 07/06/1916, boarding  C.O.H.T. “Huntspill”, disembarked Marseilles 14/06/1916, and travelled to the  Base Depot at Etaples on the northern coast of France.

Alfred was taken on strength of  B Coy,  52nd Battalion on 27/07/1916.
On 04/09/1916 52nd Battalion  took part in an attack on Monquet Farm, and Alfred  was seen lying in No Mans Land. He was subsequently posted as Missing In Action. On 24th December, Pte Donald Hector Macrostie, 2939, from Alfred’s battalion made a statement whilst he was recovering  in 3rd London General Hospital, Wandsworth, to the effect that Alfred was killed whilst being carried, wounded, on his back during an attack on Monquet Farm on 4th September 1916. Pte Mc Crostie was wounded at the same time, and therefore had no knowledge of Alfred’s burial. 

It transpired that Alfred had been buried just north of Pozieres. On 24/04/1917 a Court of Inquiry declared that Alfred had been Killed in Action. 

After the war Alfred’s body was exhumed and re-interred in Courcelette British Cemetery.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Source of some of the above info www.aif.adfa.edu.au:8080/showPerson?pid=156737 The Monquet Farm is actually Mouquet Farm. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Mouquet_Farm Quote "The Battle of Mouquet Farm, which began on 5 August 1916, was part of the Battle of the Somme and followed the Battle of Pozières. The farm was eventually captured on 26 September." AIF Memorial Mouquet Farm www.ww1cemeteries.com/othercemeteries/aifmouquetfarm.htm
